author: sky.cactus
content:
Credible neutrality is all about perception.  What *actually* happened behind closed doors doesn't matter.  What matters is that the defacto rule we (editors) have about disallowing number sniping was not followed for this EIP while it is followed for many others, and the reasoning and discussion around it was not held in a public place.  You can claim all you want that nothing sketchy happened behind the scenes, but what matters is whether or not the process *appears* to be captured or not.

A process can be neutral, but not *credibly* neutral if external people looking in on the system cannot tell whether it is neutral or not.  Similarly, a process can be credibly neutral while not actually being neutral if one can manage to hide corruption well enough.  We want the EIP process to be both actually neutral and credibly neutral.  At the least this event tarnishes the credibility of our neutrality, at the most it indicates a failure of actual neutrality (e.g., if you were given 5000 because you know lightclient in real life and were able to persuade him in a way that most authors cannot).

author: samwilsn
content:
The `GITHUB_SHA` environment variable specifies the hash that `actions/checkout` clones from git.

With a `pull_request` trigger, `GITHUB_SHA` contains the latest commit from the pull request's source branch. Also with `pull_request`, the authentication token only has read-only permissions.

With a `pull_request_target` trigger, `GITHUB_SHA` contains the latest commit from the pull request's target branch. With `pull_request_target`, the authentication token has read-write permissions.
